perturbation.original_text:
All income and credits, and all losses and deductions shall be owned and shared among the Joint Venturers as follows:
     50% to Collectible Concepts Group, Inc.
     50% to Pivotal Self Service Tech, Inc.
     Depreciation and all other charges and expenses, which are not expressly
     apportioned by this Agreement, shall be apportioned in accordance with
     generally accepted accounting principles, consistently applied.
perturbation.changed_text:
All profits and credits, and all deficits and deductions shall be owned and shared among the participants as follows:
     60% to Collectible Concepts Group, Inc.
     40% to Pivotal Self Service Tech, Inc.
     Depreciation and all other charges and expenses, which are not expressly
     apportioned by this Agreement, shall be apportioned as the management sees fit.
perturbation.explanation: The terms 'income' and 'losses' are replaced with 'profits' and 'deficits', and 'Joint Venturers' are changed to 'participants'. Also, the split percentages are modified, and the standard for apportioning expenses is removed. It’s unclear if income and profits are the same, if losses and deficits are the same, or if the participants are the same as the joint venturers. This contradicts the original equal sharing arrangement, creating uncertainty in financial obligations.

perturbation.original_text:
The Joint Venturers shall maintain adequate books
     and records to be kept of all the Joint Venture activities and affairs
     conducted pursuant to the terms of this Agreement. All direct costs and
     expenses, which shall include any insurance costs in connection with the
     distribution of the Products or operations of the Joint Venture, or if the
     business of the Joint Venture requires additional office facilities than
     those now presently maintained by each Joint Venturer, such item shall be

     paid by the Joint Venture. The fiscal year of the Joint Venture shall be
     the calendar year, and shall use the cash basis of accounting. If requested
     by a Joint Venturer, the Joint Venture books and records shall be audited
     as of the close of each year by an independent accountant acceptable to
     both Joint Venturers.
perturbation.changed_text: The participants shall maintain sufficient documentation of all joint venture activities and dealings conducted as per this agreement. All direct and indirect costs, including all insurance costs for product distribution or venture operations, will be managed. If the venture needs extra office space beyond what the participants currently have, these expenses are covered by the business. The venture’s accounting period runs from July 1 to June 30, using accrual accounting. The venture books can be reviewed annually by a mutually approved auditor at a participant’s request.
perturbation.explanation: Changed 'Joint Venturers' to 'participants,' 'adequate books and records' to 'sufficient documentation,' 'direct costs and expenses' to 'direct and indirect costs,' fiscal year from calendar year to July 1-June 30, and accounting method from 'cash basis' to 'accrual accounting'. It is unclear if participants is equal to joint venturers, if sufficient documentation equals adequate books and records, or if direct and indirect costs are the same as direct costs and expenses. It also changes the accounting practices. These modifications create contradictions about what records are kept and how, impacting financial accountability.

perturbation.original_text:
On any termination of the Joint
     Venture, its debt shall be paid or provided for in a manner satisfactory to
     the Joint Venturers. Then, any unexpended portion of Joint Venture funds
     shall be distributed to the Joint Venturers in accordance with their
     prorata ownership in the Joint Venture and all other assets of the Joint
     Venture shall be distributed as undivided interests to the Joint Venturers
     ratably according to their prorata interests in the Joint Venture as set
     forth in Section 6. If any asset is not capable of being distributed on an
     undivided basis, the Parties shall agree on a price for such asset and it
     shall be distributed to one Party and a corresponding balance, in cash or
     property, shall be made of the Joint Venture assets so that each Party
     receives his proportionate share of all the Joint Venture assets.
perturbation.changed_text: Upon termination of the Business, its liabilities will be addressed in a way the Members agree is suitable. Any remaining Business money will be given to the Members as per their stakes in the Business, and all Business assets will be shared among the Members equally. If an asset cannot be split, the Associates will decide on a value, and one Associate will get it, with the Business making up the difference to ensure each Associate gets their fair share of all Business assets.
perturbation.explanation: Replaced 'Joint Venture' with 'Business', 'Joint Venturers' with 'Members', and 'Parties' with 'Associates'. 'Prorata ownership' is replaced with 'stakes', and assets will be split 'equally' rather than 'ratably'. It is unclear if Business is the same as the Joint Venture, if Members are equal to the Joint Venturers, if Parties are equal to the Associates, or if 'stakes' means prorata ownership. Section 6 defines percentages different than equally, and by changing it, creates a contradiction. This introduces uncertainty on how assets and funds are split upon dissolution, contradicting the original pro-rata division detailed in Section 6 and creating enforcement issues.
